Sullivan | UK blowout nears perfection

Wildcats make yet another statement with rout of UCLA.

Sullivan | UK blowout nears perfection

Tim Sullivan, tsullivan@courier-journal.com 9:07 p.m. EST December 20, 2014

Kentucky players from left, Devin Booker, Tyler Ulis, Trey Lyles, and Willie Cauley-Stein celebrate their 83-42 win over UCLA during the second half of an NCAA college basketball game, Saturday, Dec. 20, 2014, in Chicago. (AP Photo/Nam Y. Huh)(Photo: AP)

2 CONNECT 8 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

CHICAGO – Before UCLA finally scored Saturday afternoon, Willie Cauley-Stein had spent enough time at the scorer's table to establish residency.

Kentucky's' tattooed titan started the game, left the floor twice for substitutions, and returned to the fray two other times to find UK's shutout still intact. It was 24-0 before the Bruins finally broke through, then 41-7 at the half, and finally, mercifully, 83-44.

Video | John Calipari on Kentucky's rout of UCLA

This was college basketball's version of Groundhog Day, except whenever a UCLA player saw his shadow, there was usually a Kentucky arm rising above it to swat his shot away.

"We couldn't get to the basket how we wanted," UCLA's Kevon Looney said. "And when we did get there, it wasn't easy to finish."

The names change, the numbers fluctuate, but the central theme of Kentucky's season grows increasingly redundant. Getting a clear lane or a clean look against the Wildcats is like moving a tractor through a muddy thicket, except that the trees don't stand still and are constantly augmented by fresh growth.

COURIER-JOURNAL

Kentucky basketball rolls to rout of UCLA

Saturday, the Wildcats blocked 13 shots and allowed only 19 field goals. They held a UCLA team that had been averaging 80.8 points per game 29 points beneath its previous low and allowed the Bruins to sink just 26.8 percent of their shots from the field. Already the nation's top-ranked team, Kentucky recorded its 12th straight double-digit victory in a fashion so emphatic as to inspire awe and fuel expectations of an undefeated season.

If opponents are "licking their chops" for a shot at these Wildcats, as UK coach John Calipari said Thursday, they must savor the taste of their own blood.

"I don't know in my 20 years of coaching at the Division I level that I've coached against a better team than what this team looks like," UCLA coach Steve Alford said of Kentucky. "They have everything."

Video | UK's Ulis, Booker on throttling UCLA

Calipari's team is so deep that Saturday's leading scorer, freshman Devin Booker, did not even enter the game until the Wildcats had already scored the game's 16 points. The Cats were able to get seven rebounds out of its petite backup point guard, Tyler Ulis, who is listed at 5-foot-9, and the stat sheet showed one blocked shot that might have been credited to any of three UK players.

Barring another significant injury, such as the torn knee ligament that has sidelined forward Alex Poythress, it is increasingly difficult to imagine the Wildcats stumbling en route to the NCAA Championship. Shorter-term, there's not another ranked opponent on UK's regular season schedule after next Saturday's rivalry game against No. 4 Louisville.

"The scary part about them," Alford said, "(is) I think they can probably still get better as they continue to get more and more experience and they go along (undefeated). ... As it grows, I think a lot of times you think that there becomes more pressure. (But) I think as it grows, they're going to get hungrier with it.

COURIER-JOURNAL

Kentucky-UCLA basketball live blog

"Just looking at their demeanor, this thing reaches 18, 19, 20 in a row, you may not get them because I think they'll get really hungry and think that they can do it now."

What few doubts have been expressed about this UK team have largely concerned Calipari's ability to provide elite players enough playing time to prevent grumbling. Yet if any fissures have developed, if any friction has been felt, the players continue to project contentment with their roles and a growing appreciation of their shared possibilities.

"We have to keep playing against ourselves," Booker said. "Coach always stresses to us that we're not playing against the other team, we're against ourselves."

Such statements might seem immodest, but they are not inaccurate. What the Wildcats face each day in practice is more daunting than anything they've seen thus far in games. With each new lopsided victory, it becomes progressively plain that this is a team playing for posterity.

    Alford, who starred on Indiana's 1987 NCAA Championship team, said Kentucky reminded him of a team Bobby Knight always envisioned but never coached – one with five jumbo-sized players, each of them capable of guarding from the post to the perimeter.

    "They're really good defensively," Alford said. "They can switch on you, they guard the pick-and-rolls well and then, when you beat them – and I thought we did, we got some angles, we beat them — then you've got two guys 6-10, 6-11 (or) 7-foot. One of them jumps. If he misses (the block), the other one gets it. You don't see that kind of size, and I think that affects you, and that's hard to prepare for."

    And even harder to play against.

    Tim Sullivan can be reached at (502) 582-4650, by email at tsullivan@courier-journal.com, and on Twitter @TimSullivan714
